awd_titl_txt: LEAP-HI: Embedding Regional Hurricane Risk Management in the Life of a Community: A Computational Framework
awd_abstract_narration:
The effort in this Leading Engineering for America's Prosperity, Health, and Infrastructure (LEAP-HI) award provides a scientific framework for evaluating the risks of hurricanes to residential communities and public policies to manage them.  Disaster losses in the United States continue to grow despite a wealth of interdisciplinary knowledge and many interventions intended to minimize their effects. A breakthrough in disaster risk reduction requires an approach that views disasters not as abnormal events, but as a regular part of a community's evolution and that recognizes that disaster risk management is inextricably interwoven with the normal activities of everyday life. A novel computational modeling framework will implement this approach to understand escalating regional natural disaster risks and support the design of public policy interventions to address them. The system-wide analysis framework will consider the perspectives of and interactions among multiple key stakeholders (government, primary insurers, and homeowners), multiple interventions (home strengthening, insurance, land use planning), and secondary factors that affect risk. The framework will directly support management of the country's natural disaster risk and promise long-term societal benefits through improved quality of life and economic competitiveness. Collaboration with representatives of the home building and insurance industries and relevant government agencies will help ensure practical results and wide dissemination. Summer internships for William A. Anderson Fund Graduate Student Fellows, all scholars from underrepresented groups, will help broaden participation in disaster research and practice. 

The Multistakeholder Disaster Risk Management (MDRM) computational framework will include seven interacting mathematical models representing physically-based simulations of damage, losses, and ways to strengthen homes; decision-making by each main stakeholder type (government, primary insurers, and homeowners) including oligopolistic competition among insurers; and the changing building inventory and regional economy that provide the context. It will build on an existing framework that the investigators have developed, expanding it through the integration of six tasks: (1) Identify a broad range of government interventions, including both risk-focused and risk-influential actions; (2) Develop a new empirically-based homeowner decision model that considers the process by which homeowners initiate risk-focused and risk-influential decisions; (3) Develop a dynamic model of the insurance market;  (4) Develop a dynamic building inventory model; (5) Develop a dynamic regional economic model that interacts with the building inventory; and (6) Conduct a full-scale case study for hurricanes in North Carolina. This project promises improved understanding of the creation and management of regional natural disaster risk by, for the first time, uniting the conceptualization of disasters as part of the normal life of a community with the power of quantitative, dynamic engineering modeling of risk, decision-making, and economics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary outcome of this project is development of the Stakeholder-based Tool for the Analysis of Regional Risk (STARR), a software model designed to inform the creation and analysis of government policies for regional disaster risk management. STARR consists of seven interacting modules. Three describe the decision-making of, respectively, government agencies, insurers, and households; and four (hazard, damage and loss, buildings, economy) describe the natural, built, and economic environments in which those decisions are made. The tool is intended to: (1) support policy-making by facilitating development, evaluation, and comparison of possible disaster risk management policies; (2) facilitate understanding of the dynamic system of regional disaster risk management, including interactions among stakeholder decisions and the effects of changes in the context or assumptions; and (3) guide future research in a way that tightly integrates social science, physical science, and engineering contributions, demonstrating the interrelation among research advances, building on previous research, and identifying lingering gaps in knowledge. While it is possible to extend the framework to consider other hazards and stakeholders, STARR currently focuses on hurricanes and on households and housing. It accounts for changes over time and uncertainty in hurricane occurrence and effects. Importantly, to try to bridge the gap between disaster risk management knowledge and actual implementation of changes in the real world, STARR is intended to design policies and programs that are likely to actually be implemented because (1) they align with the way stakeholders naturally make decisions, and (2) they produce win-win outcomes that are better for everyone.

In addition, the project provided many more specific disciplinary advances. 

  1. To better understand why homeowners tend not to strengthen their homes to reduce hurricane damage,  we developed a new analysis approach that, for the first time, treats the decision to retrofit as a multi-stage process. The approach combines three key components that have not previously been employed together: (1) the Precaution Adoption Process Model as a theoretical framework, (2) a dataset merging mitigation program data and survey data, and (3) a multi-state Markov model as a quantitative representation of the process. This new method allows us to understand how long the full process takes; where along the way people are likely to get stuck; and at each stage, what factors are associated with an increased likelihood of transitioning to the next stage.  

  2. We convened a diverse group of 100 practitioners engaged in disaster risk mitigation to (1) identify objectives of mitigation-focused participants as well as competing and complementary objectives of others, and (2) assess the strengths and limitations of various risk management tools.

  3. The built environment is always changing in ways that can dramatically affect disaster risk. Nevertheless, disaster risk models have typically assumed it is static. With this in mind, we developed the Housing Inventory Projection (HIP) method to estimate regional changes in a region’s housing inventory for natural hazards loss modeling purposes. We used it to compare the effects of different land use policies on the projected number and distribution of houses throughout a region, and the resulting hurricane risk and property tax revenue. 

  4. The more fully and accurately we can describe hurricane damage and loss in past events and predict them for future events, the better insurers and public officials can effectively respond to and plan for them. Working with our practitioner partners, we used insurance claims data for four recent hurricanes to develop machine learning models that predict residential hurricane wind damage and loss. The models predict accurately enough to be useful for many practical purposes.

  5. We adapted a computable general equilibrium model to estimate hurricane impacts on regional GDP and income by income group and incorporated it into the STARR framework. Experiments with the models showed that the purchase of adequate insurance is central to recovery for households and the economy after a hurricane event. They also demonstrate the critical importance of affordable insurance for lower income homeowners and that in the absence of such insurance pools, low income individuals see a disproportion decline in the equity in their homes over time as sequences of storms lead to damage that this population of homeowners can not afford to repair.

  6. We investigated two different ways to understand how homeowners make risk-related decisions. One assumes they have an accurate understanding of the hurricane hazard; the other is based on their survey responses. Results with the former approach reducing losses more effectively, suggesting that education could help homeowners manage their risk.

Four postdoctoral researchers, 9 PhD students, 1 Master’s student, and 3 undergraduates were trained through this project. They were students and postdocs in civil engineering, economics, sociology, and disaster science and management.

The project resulted in publication of at least 18 peer-reviewed journal papers, 3 software codes, 1 book chapters, 1 technical report, and 4 theses.
